bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT, WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
In the Matter of the Appli- cation of LEWIS JOHNSON for a Writ of Habeas Cor- pus.
THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA, WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON. )() ss.
WINTER S. MARTIN, being first duly sworn, upon oath deposes and says:
That he is an Assistant United States Attorney for the Western District of Washington, and makes this affidavit for and on behlaf of the United States of America.

Affiant deposes that on the 30th day of July, 1915, there was received at the office of the United States Attorney, 310 Federal Building, Seattle, Washington the following telegram from the Secretary of State for the United States, at Washington, D.C., to-wit:
"Washington, D.C., Jul. 30, 1915.

Clay Allen, U.S. Atty., Seattle, Wash. Department sent British Embassy warrant surrender for Johnson July Nineteenth. Original record being part Department's filed cannot be returned. Robt. Lansing, Secy of State."

That upon the hearing of the above entitled cause upon the writ of habeas corpus in the above entitled court on August 30, 1915, it was stipulated in open court that a telegram from the Department of State, showing in whose name the demand for the extradition of Lewis Johnson had
been made, would be accepted in lieu of certified copies of original documents, duly authenticated.
Pursuant to said stipulation affiant telegraphed the Attorney General of the United States for information in the premises and received the following telegram from said Attorney General:
"Washington, D.C., Sept. 1-15.
U.S. Attorney, Seattle, Wn.

Replying to your wire Aug. thirieth following telegram has been received today from State Department quote, answering your telegram of Aug. Thirty First Nineteen Fifteen reference extradition Lewis Johnson you are informed that on July thirteenth last British Ambassa- dor made request of the Secretary of State in usual form for extradition this man, and accordingly on July Nineteenth last a warrant of surrender was sent to the British Ambassador.
Robert Lansing, Secretary of State.
End quote.
Davis, Acting Attorney General."

Affiant further deposes that William McRae, Deputy Constantable for the city of Vancouver, British Colombia, has presented to him his warrant from Robert Lansing, Secretary of State of the United States of America, for the extradi- tion of Lewis Johnson, which said warrant is in words and figures as follows, to-wit:
"DEPARTMENT OF STATE. TO ALL TO WHOM THESE PRESENTS SHALL COME, GREETING:

Whereas, His Excellency Sir Cecil Arthur Spring Rice, Ambassador Extraordinary and Plenipotentiary of Great Britain, accredited to this Government, has made requisi- tion in conformity with the provisions of existing treaty stipulations between the United States of America and Great Britain for the mutual delivery of criminals, fugitives from justice in certain cases, for the delivery up of Lewis Johnston, or Johnson, charged with the crime of larceny, committed within the jurisdiction of the British Government;

And whereas, the said Lewis Johnston, or Johnson, has been found within the jurisdiction of the United States and has, by proper authority and due form of law, been brought before John G. Whitlock, Commissioner in Extradition for the Western District of Washington, for examination upon said charge of larceny;

And whereas, the said Commissioner has found and adjudged that the evidence produced against the said Lewis Johnston,, or Johnson, is sufficient in law to justify his commitment upon the said charge, and has, therefore, ordered that the said Lewis Johnston, or Johnson, be committed pursuant to the provisions of said treaty stipulations.

Now, therefore, pursuant to the provisions of Section 5272 of the Revised Statutes of the United States, These Presents are to require the United States Marshal for the Western District of Washington, or any other public officer or person having charge or custody of the aforesaid Lewis Johnston, or Johnson, to surrender and deliver him up to
such person or persons as may be duly authorized by the Government of Great Britain to receive the said Lewis Johnston, or Johnson, to be tried for the crime of which he is so accused.
In testimony whereof, I have hereunto signed my name and caused the seal of the Department of State to be affixed.
Done at the City of Washington, this 19th day of July, A.D. 1915, and of the Independence of the United States the 140th.

figure.p: DEPARTMENT OF STATE :::: SEAL :::: UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

div1.p: ROBERT LANSING Secretary of State."
and that this said warrant will be produced in this cause for the Court's inspection.

That by reason of the foregoing documents, affiant deposes and avers that demand was made in the name of the British Ambassador for and on behalf of Great Britain, and that the same was in all respects regular and complied with the statutes in such case made and provided.
William S. Martin
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 2nd day of September, 1915. Albert Moodiy Notary Public in and for the State of Washington, residing at Seattle.
